commit_message:
Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'glance_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable glance_galera_address which
has been used for a long time, but never documented.

Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/568485
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/568492
Change-Id: I1a875cfdece088838027fc7b4dafd812d8c2693b

commit_message:
Ensure facts are updated for new containers

When the new containers are built, we currently only collect
a minimal amount of facts afterwards. This patch ensures that
a broader set of facts are updated to ensure that we have the
updated distribution information, networking and storage facts.

We do this for both types of containers to ensure consistency
in the approach.

Related-Bug: 1765438
Change-Id: I620e35d0942a6d4a55e05ae441d0e6ee2e4a67c4

- gate-grenade-dsvm-ironic http://logs.openstack.org/02/336102/5/check/gate-grenade-dsvm-ironic/95e087e/ : SUCCESS in 1h 09m 59s'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2016-07-01 14:42:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hello Lucas,

There is patch that configured devstack syslog listener: 
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/336458/
COLLECT_LOGS_FROM_BOOTSTRAP is a trigger variable.

And patch that enables sending syslog on tinycore:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/336527/

Indeed there seems to be no syslog daemon at coreos, but it is possible to send messages to remote syslog via running 'logger' in background:

journalctl -f | logger -n <server_ip>

The patches are PoC, but they shows that it is possible to use syslog for Ironic needs.
I still think that sending logs should be solved by syslog or other native linux tools. Ironic is not proper place to solve this task.
I appreciate your effort on it, there are a lot of code was developed. But I think that we should reopen spec and discuss possibility of syslog usage. What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 14629, 'date': '2016-07-01 16:03:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

[{'created': '2016-06-30 16:15:06.000000000', 'message': 'Collect deployment logs from IPA

This patch adds the code to collect the deployment logs from the IPA
ramdisk. The logs can be collect for every deployment, upon a failure or
never. By default, logs are never collected.

After collection, logs can be storaged either in the local fileystem
(default) or in Swift.

If an error occurs when the logs are being collected, storaged or if the
ramdisk does not support the collect_system_logs command Ironic will log
an error message, but the deployment will proceed.

Closes-Bug: #1587143
Change-Id: I6da1110daa94ea25670f71f9862e51cc9bbc6f93

commit_message:
Collect deployment logs from IPA

This patch adds the code to collect the deployment logs from the IPA
ramdisk. The logs can be collect for every deployment, upon a failure or
never. By default, logs are collected upon a failure.

After collection, logs can be storaged either in the local filesystem
(default) or in Swift.

If an error occurs when the logs are being collected, storaged or if the
ramdisk does not support the collect_system_logs command Ironic will log
an error message, but the deployment will proceed.

Documentation on how to enable and other configuration will be done on a
subsequent patch.

Partial-Bug: #1587143
Change-Id: I6da1110daa94ea25670f71f9862e51cc9bbc6f93

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-15 03:18:28.000000000', 'message': "Enable quota system and set qgroups

This change implements the machinectl quota system and qgroups when
they're enabled and available. This change is being implemented to
resolve an issue where machinectl based containers using a loopback file
system spam DMESG with the following:

* BTRFS error (device loop0): could not find root $INT

While various upstream sources say this error is benign[0], it raises
an inconsistency flag within the host system and is speculatively the
cause of our inconsistent read-only/Full-FS issues we've seen in the
integrated gate. Once the qgroups are properly setup the system will
remove the inconsistency flag and the message spam will stop.

* BTRFS info (device loop0): qgroup scan completed (inconsistency flag cleared)

To resolve this issue the quota system is being enabled by default
and unlimited qgroups are being setup to ensure we're not running
into file system limitations. This change essentially acknowledges
the built-in quota system and provides for the ability to set /
define specific quota (qgroup) options as necessary. While many
deployers may never use these options or this tooling, the role will
now properly set everything up should it ever be needed.

[0] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/1651435
Change-Id: I34a41ac8a9fe4419254284c83f4600efee274c04
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Enable quota system and set qgroups

This change implements the machinectl quota system and qgroups when
they're enabled and available. This change is being implemented to
resolve an issue where machinectl based containers using a loopback file
system spam DMESG with the following:

* BTRFS error (device loop0): could not find root $INT

While various upstream sources say this error is benign[0], it raises
an inconsistency flag within the host system and is speculatively the
cause of our inconsistent read-only/Full-FS issues we've seen in the
integrated gate. Once the qgroups are properly setup the system will
remove the inconsistency flag and the message spam will stop.

* BTRFS info (device loop0): qgroup scan completed (inconsistency flag cleared)

To resolve this issue the quota system is being enabled by default
and unlimited qgroups are being setup to ensure we're not running
into file system limitations. This change essentially acknowledges
the built-in quota system and provides for the ability to set /
define specific quota (qgroup) options as necessary. While many
deployers may never use these options or this tooling, the role will
now properly set everything up should it ever be needed.

[0] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/1651435
Closes-Bug: #1753790
Change-Id: I34a41ac8a9fe4419254284c83f4600efee274c04
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for 15.1.22

This patch updates all the roles to the latest available stable
SHA's, copies the release notes from the updated roles into the
integrated repo, updates all the OpenStack Service SHA's, and
updates the appropriate python requirements pins.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/568154
Change-Id: I7b3b2c9e9005934b1dae444d122e4bafc5609c00

commit_message:
Only implement openrc/clouds.yaml on a designated host

The openrc role will no longer be executed on all OpenStack
service containers/hosts. Instead a single host is designated
through the use of the ``openstack_service_setup_host``
variable. The default is ``localhost`` (the deployment host).

While each playbook previously executed the role, it did not
need to as the role is already in each service role's meta
dependencies.

Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/568142
Change-Id: I7bb90264ee379db5410e7ec16c5bac1ee2c398dc

commit_message:
Require the (soon-to-be) Rocky version of Horizon

... or at least the first published tarball which will lead to Rocky.
On the other side this means forcing the usage of mox as long as
there are tests that depends on it (the switch was already flipped
in Horizon, so it needs to be enabled here).

This allows us to depend on newer Horizon features, including changes
to the test suite that are useful for the mox removal effort.

Also remove mox since there are no unit tests that need it.

Change-Id: Ia8e0d5512f11e3d191ca2f6259075e35490290c2
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <zulcss@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Remove requirements file names from output

In https://review.openstack.org/567646 this line (which was
used for debugging) was included by mistake. Leaving it there
results in malformed yaml when executing the py_pkgs plugin
from a console, so it must be removed.

Change-Id: I58a76109c272b0be384c4113069f48415e8ab010

commit_message:
Remove keystone_authtoken section for ceilometer

Now, the ceilometer use [service_credentials] to get credentials[0][1],
remove the unused [keystone_authtoken]

[0]: https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/blob/master/devstack/plugin.sh#L294
[1]: https://docs.openstack.org/ceilometer/latest/configuration/index.html

Change-Id: Ic92f9ecb1a43c11311f2a428611e78c0986f02cf

[{'created': '2018-05-14 11:53:58.000000000', 'message': "Delete internal ports for ERROR-ed nodes

Precreated ports are never deleted by nova,
thus heat must delete the ports that it creates
that are internal ports.

This is important when baremetal is used via
ironic where the MAC address of the port must
match the physical node. Neutron does not
permit duplicate MAC addresses, hence ports
can't be orphaned.

Change-Id: I965abefbb10c22a635c35e3a44d227045f33885c
Story: #1766763
Task: #18791
(cherry picked from commit 5692d59007595b4fb2fb5aa9498c43a43ba5361d)
"}]
commit_message:
Delete internal ports for ERROR-ed nodes

Precreated ports are never deleted by nova,
thus heat must delete the ports that it creates
that are internal ports.

This is important when baremetal is used via
ironic where the MAC address of the port must
match the physical node. Neutron does not
permit duplicate MAC addresses, hence ports
can't be orphaned.

Change-Id: I965abefbb10c22a635c35e3a44d227045f33885c
Story: #1766763
Task: #18791
(cherry picked from commit 5692d59007595b4fb2fb5aa9498c43a43ba5361d)

commit_message:
Call L3 checks before/after Role upgrade.

It worth calling L3-agent checks before and after each role
is upgrade.
This helps to narrow down when the packet loss or L3 failover
occurs.

Change-Id: I058d0171266c21f9ec398018095fd73d8597b745

subject: Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately
messages:
[{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-05-09 09:07:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch stable/queens.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-05-09 09:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-05-09 11:21:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

check experimental'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-05-15 11:30:58.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning until https://review.openstack.org/567137 merges.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-05-15 13:46:54.000000000', 'content': 'Restored'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-05-15 13:47:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-05-15 13:48:33.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to bug/1768592-stable/pike'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-05-15 14:11:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-05-15 14:26:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-09 09:07:23.000000000', 'message': "Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately

The implementation of I3769053956b958a0ac7cab499ea90af2a40de850
was somewhat brutal in the approach based on the assumption that
systemd networking is implemented in the base cache. This may be
true for Rocky, but is not true for any of the older branches.

This patch returns the previous method, but fixes it in two ways:

1. It uses the -f file test operator, instead of the deprecated
   -a operator.
2. It also tests for the presence of a symbolic link with -L.

The downloaded image has resolvconf installed, so there is a symlink
for /etc/resolv.conf which points to /run/resolvconf/resolv.conf
in the cache. Given that in a chroot /run does not exist, the file
test operator fails. This is why we're adding the symlink check.

Instead of then removing resolv.conf at the end, we return it back
so that resolveconf works as expected. This is important for anyone
implementing their resolvers through configuration of network
interfaces.

This is only implemented for Queens and older because for master
the image source changes, and the implementation changes to be
fully systemd-based which works differently.

Change-Id: I11d069e2d0cb3becad067689fa8f1e4c9391f368
"}, {'created': '2018-05-15 13:47:05.000000000', 'message': "Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately

The implementation of I3769053956b958a0ac7cab499ea90af2a40de850
was somewhat brutal in the approach based on the assumption that
systemd networking is implemented in the base cache. This may be
true for Rocky, but is not true for any of the older branches.

This patch returns the previous method, but fixes it in two ways:

1. It uses the -f file test operator, instead of the deprecated
   -a operator.
2. It also tests for the presence of a symbolic link with -L.

The downloaded image has resolvconf installed, so there is a symlink
for /etc/resolv.conf which points to /run/resolvconf/resolv.conf
in the cache. Given that in a chroot /run does not exist, the file
test operator fails. This is why we're adding the symlink check.

Instead of then removing resolv.conf at the end, we return it back
so that resolveconf works as expected. This is important for anyone
implementing their resolvers through configuration of network
interfaces.

This is only implemented for Queens and older because for master
we've moved to using a different image source, and using
systemd-resolved.

Closes-Bug: #1768592
Change-Id: I11d069e2d0cb3becad067689fa8f1e4c9391f368
(cherry picked from commit ed7270e8146718c5b278026c49b5135572b6fc25)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately

The implementation of I3769053956b958a0ac7cab499ea90af2a40de850
was somewhat brutal in the approach based on the assumption that
systemd networking is implemented in the base cache. This may be
true for Rocky, but is not true for any of the older branches.

This patch returns the previous method, but fixes it in two ways:

1. It uses the -f file test operator, instead of the deprecated
   -a operator.
2. It also tests for the presence of a symbolic link with -L.

The downloaded image has resolvconf installed, so there is a symlink
for /etc/resolv.conf which points to /run/resolvconf/resolv.conf
in the cache. Given that in a chroot /run does not exist, the file
test operator fails. This is why we're adding the symlink check.

Instead of then removing resolv.conf at the end, we return it back
so that resolveconf works as expected. This is important for anyone
implementing their resolvers through configuration of network
interfaces.

This is only implemented for Queens and older because for master
we've moved to using a different image source, and using
systemd-resolved.

Closes-Bug: #1768592
Change-Id: I11d069e2d0cb3becad067689fa8f1e4c9391f368
(cherry picked from commit ed7270e8146718c5b278026c49b5135572b6fc25)

commit_message:
Use predictable name for generated hiera overrides

Ditch NamedTemporaryFile where it is not really needed.
Similarly to a static 'tripleoclient-hosts-portmaps.yaml',
use 'tripleo-hieradata-override.yaml' for the hieradata
generated file.

Change-Id: I437b8b552b4e6debfd9559977b1d001697106235
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

Actually i'm not sure about this. The problem is I think we already recommend templates/ in docs so this might collide. I'm ok with simplifying the tmp folder we use where currently it's <named-random>/templates, and we could drop the extra level. But i don't think we can/should use 'templates' as the folder name."}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-05-07 17:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-05-08 07:36:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

@Alex, it is actually composed of output_dir/templates. So users may alter it via customizing output_dir, e.g. $HOME/tripleo'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-05-08 07:43:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

hm, the docs https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-docs/latest/install/advanced_deployment/template_deploy.html look good : 

openstack overcloud deploy --templates /home/stack/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates

will not collide'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-05-08 13:55:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Downstream docs and end users have used ~/templates for their copy for years. If you want to follow up with a change that's fine but we cannot continue with ~/templates as the default because people won't change it and it will cause problems. Like I said, i'm ok with dropping the extra hierarchy that we had which was causing some pathing problems (e.g. remove the templates folder from undercloud-<random>-templates/templates) but I think this is not the solution. I think it's covering up for other issues when we switch away from handling relative pathing via swift from the overcloud for the all in one.  The rendered path needs to be a random temp location and we need to solve for the relative path lookups like we do for the overcloud deployment."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-05-08 14:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-05-09 07:53:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-05-09 09:28:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

If you believe we've correctly identified the failure, feel free to leave a 'recheck' comment to run the tests again.
For more details on this and other bugs, please see http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-05-14 07:45:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Patch Set 12 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-05-14 11:46:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-30 14:52:42.000000000', 'message': "Consume deployed t-h-t from the working output dir

The working output dir contains the deployed templates,
including those processed from j2. These can't be used in env
file args, if referenced from the given --templates path, as never
existed/deployed under that path.

Also, the working directory can not be neither ephemeral, nor
given a random name as users might reference generated j2 files,
by a **predicted** names, for deployments and expect those to be
preserved, not cleaned up, when deployment ends or fails.

Fix rewriting templates paths to use that working output dir as
a new base, to allow users reference the rendered j2 files as
custom env files from the expected path.

Change-Id: Ic7b8c36804124463a1b0582e3aeeb3019729686b
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2018-04-30 14:57:08.000000000', 'message': "Consume deployed t-h-t from the working output dir

The working output dir contains the deployed templates,
including those processed from j2. These can't be used in env
file args, if referenced from the given --templates path, as never

Also, the working directory can not be neither ephemeral, nor
given a random name as users might reference generated j2 files,
by a **predicted** names, for deployments and expect those to be
preserved, not cleaned up, when deployment ends or fails.

Fix rewriting templates paths to use that working output dir as
a new base, to allow users reference the rendered j2 files as
custom env files from the expected path.

Closes-bug: #1765358
Related-bug: #1749683

Change-Id: Ic7b8c36804124463a1b0582e3aeeb3019729686b

commit_message:
Consume deployed t-h-t from the working output dir

The working output dir contains the deployed templates,
including those processed from j2. These can't be used in env
file args, if referenced from the given --templates path, as never
existed/deployed under that path.

Also the working directory should not be given a random name as
users might reference generated j2 files,
by a **predicted** names, for deployments

Fix rewriting templates paths to use that working
output dir/tripleo-heat-installer-templates path as
a new base, to allow users reference the rendered j2 files as
custom env files from the expected path.

Closes-bug: #1765358
Related-bug: #1749683

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/566904
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/566905
Change-Id: Ic7b8c36804124463a1b0582e3aeeb3019729686b
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
__str__ methods for RequestGroup, ResourceRequest

To make prettier log messages and aid debugging, add __str__ methods to
nova.api.openstack.placement.lib.RequestGroup and
nova.scheduler.utils.ResourceRequest and use the latter (which uses the
former) in the log message in
nova.scheduler.client.report.SchedulerReportClient.get_allocation_candidates

Change-Id: I80b2427fabc4004a9a8ce1e45fc46031ce9aadda

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-09 10:43:01.000000000', 'message': "Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately

The implementation of I3769053956b958a0ac7cab499ea90af2a40de850
was somewhat brutal in the approach based on the assumption that
systemd networking is implemented in the base cache. This may be
true for Rocky, but is not true for any of the older branches.

This patch returns the previous method, but fixes it in two ways:

1. It uses the -f file test operator, instead of the deprecated
   -a operator.
2. It also tests for the presence of a symbolic link with -L.

The downloaded image has resolvconf installed, so there is a symlink
for /etc/resolv.conf which points to /run/resolvconf/resolv.conf
in the cache. Given that in a chroot /run does not exist, the file
test operator fails. This is why we're adding the symlink check.

Instead of then removing resolv.conf at the end, we return it back
so that resolveconf works as expected. This is important for anyone
implementing their resolvers through configuration of network
interfaces.

This is only implemented for Queens and older because for master
the image source changes, and the implementation changes to be
fully systemd-based which works differently.

Change-Id: I11d069e2d0cb3becad067689fa8f1e4c9391f368
"}, {'created': '2018-05-15 13:49:14.000000000', 'message': "Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately

The implementation of I3769053956b958a0ac7cab499ea90af2a40de850
was somewhat brutal in the approach based on the assumption that
systemd networking is implemented in the base cache. This may be
true for Rocky, but is not true for any of the older branches.

This patch returns the previous method, but fixes it in two ways:

1. It uses the -f file test operator, instead of the deprecated
   -a operator.
2. It also tests for the presence of a symbolic link with -L.

The downloaded image has resolvconf installed, so there is a symlink
for /etc/resolv.conf which points to /run/resolvconf/resolv.conf
in the cache. Given that in a chroot /run does not exist, the file
test operator fails. This is why we're adding the symlink check.

Instead of then removing resolv.conf at the end, we return it back
so that resolveconf works as expected. This is important for anyone
implementing their resolvers through configuration of network
interfaces.

This is only implemented for Queens and older because for master
we've moved to using a different image source, and using
systemd-resolved.

Closes-Bug: #1768592
Change-Id: I11d069e2d0cb3becad067689fa8f1e4c9391f368
(cherry picked from commit ed7270e8146718c5b278026c49b5135572b6fc25)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately

The implementation of I3769053956b958a0ac7cab499ea90af2a40de850
was somewhat brutal in the approach based on the assumption that
systemd networking is implemented in the base cache. This may be
true for Rocky, but is not true for any of the older branches.

This patch returns the previous method, but fixes it in two ways:

1. It uses the -f file test operator, instead of the deprecated
   -a operator.
2. It also tests for the presence of a symbolic link with -L.

The downloaded image has resolvconf installed, so there is a symlink
for /etc/resolv.conf which points to /run/resolvconf/resolv.conf
in the cache. Given that in a chroot /run does not exist, the file
test operator fails. This is why we're adding the symlink check.

Instead of then removing resolv.conf at the end, we return it back
so that resolveconf works as expected. This is important for anyone
implementing their resolvers through configuration of network
interfaces.

This is only implemented for Queens and older because for master
we've moved to using a different image source, and using
systemd-resolved.

Closes-Bug: #1768592
Change-Id: I11d069e2d0cb3becad067689fa8f1e4c9391f368
(cherry picked from commit ed7270e8146718c5b278026c49b5135572b6fc25)

commit_message:
Replace deprecated "auth_uri" by "www_authenticate_uri"

According to [1], "auth_uri" has been deprecated.
This patch replace it by using "www_authenticate_uri" instead.

Note that: the same patch has been merged [2],
however, there's still "auth_uri" remaining in the comment
and it might confuses the users.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508522
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558386

commit_message:
Django 2.0 support

Replaces django.core.urlresolves with django.urls.
(In Django 2.0) The django.core.urlresolvers module is removed
in favor of its new location, django.urls.
It was deprecated in Django 1.10:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/releases/1.10/#id3

The arguments of include() has been changed in Django 1.9
and the older style was dropped in Django 2.0.
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/releases/1.9/#passing-a-3-tuple-or-an-app-name-to-include

Add py35dj20 job to test Django 2.0 integration.

Change-Id: I1cdfc19c9fae5cad1adac0867f65d2ae15385d87

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-26 12:52:01.000000000', 'message': 'ref driver: use decorators for registry callbacks

Using decorators has a few benefits:
- readability: what event triggers a callback is described
  next to the method definition
- subclass can cleanly change the event that the mother
  class chose to trigger a callback
- a bit less verbose in the end

Change-Id: Ia5ced2f936add5e5e3387e62273bce626d40b7a6
'}]
commit_message:
ref driver: use decorators for registry callbacks

Using decorators has a few benefits:
- readability: what event triggers a callback is described
  next to the method definition
- subclass can cleanly change the event that the mother
  class chose to trigger a callback
- a bit less verbose in the end

Change-Id: Ia5ced2f936add5e5e3387e62273bce626d40b7a6

commit_message:
Add support for certs from the tls-certs relation

* Add method for requesting certificates: get_certificate_requests
* Update get_certs_and_keys to process certs from vault relation
* Create a default handler for certificates_available

Change-Id: If24621f2e72b66d58ea15cadeb458cadaf86a483

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-09 07:30:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately

The implementation of I3769053956b958a0ac7cab499ea90af2a40de850
was somewhat brutal in the approach based on the assumption that
systemd networking is implemented in the base cache. This may be
true for Rocky, but is not true for any of the older branches.

This patch returns the previous method, but fixes it in two ways:

1. It uses the -e file test operator, instead of the deprecated
   -a operator.
2. It tests for the presence of a symbolic link too.

The downloaded image has resolvd installed, so there is a symlink
for /etc/resolv.conf which points to /run/resolvconf/resolv.conf
in the cache. Given that in a chroot /run does not exist, the file
test operator fails. This is why we're adding the symlink check.

Instead of then removing resolv.conf at the end, we return it back
so that resolveconf works as expected. This is important for anyone
implementing their resolvers through configuration of network
interfaces.

Change-Id: I11d069e2d0cb3becad067689fa8f1e4c9391f368
"}, {'created': '2018-05-09 07:31:52.000000000', 'message': "Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately

was somewhat brutal in the approach based on the assumption that
systemd networking is implemented in the base cache. This may be
true for Rocky, but is not true for any of the older branches.

This patch returns the previous method, but fixes it in two ways:

1. It uses the -e file test operator, instead of the deprecated
   -a operator.
2. It tests for the presence of a symbolic link too.

The downloaded image has resolvd installed, so there is a symlink
for /etc/resolv.conf which points to /run/resolvconf/resolv.conf
in the cache. Given that in a chroot /run does not exist, the file
test operator fails. This is why we're adding the symlink check.

Instead of then removing resolv.conf at the end, we return it back
so that resolveconf works as expected. This is important for anyone
implementing their resolvers through configuration of network
interfaces.

This is only implemented for Queens and older because for master
the image source changes from the LXC source, and the implementation
changes to be systemd-based which works differently.

Change-Id: I11d069e2d0cb3becad067689fa8f1e4c9391f368

commit_message:
Fix LXC cache resolvers more appropriately

The implementation of I3769053956b958a0ac7cab499ea90af2a40de850
was somewhat brutal in the approach based on the assumption that
systemd networking is implemented in the base cache. This may be
true for Rocky, but is not true for any of the older branches.

This patch returns the previous method, but fixes it in two ways:

1. It uses the -f file test operator, instead of the deprecated
   -a operator.
2. It also tests for the presence of a symbolic link with -L.

The downloaded image has resolvconf installed, so there is a symlink
for /etc/resolv.conf which points to /run/resolvconf/resolv.conf
in the cache. Given that in a chroot /run does not exist, the file
test operator fails. This is why we're adding the symlink check.

Instead of then removing resolv.conf at the end, we return it back
so that resolveconf works as expected. This is important for anyone
implementing their resolvers through configuration of network
interfaces.

This is only implemented for Queens and older because for master
we've moved to using a different image source, and using
systemd-resolved.

Closes-Bug: #1768592
Change-Id: I11d069e2d0cb3becad067689fa8f1e4c9391f368

commit_message:
Support devpi as the upstream pip server

devpi serves packages from url starting +f/. The devpi source code
suggets that +e may also be used but is not seen when using devpi
as a caching proxy.

This patch adds a tool to be able to monitor the OpenDaylight cluster

commit_message:
Adds re-factored clustering monitoring tool

This patch adds a tool to be able to monitor the OpenDaylight cluster
using a json config file created by a user/operator.  The tool is a
re-factor of a script used in OpenDaylight integration/test repo here:
https://github.com/opendaylight/integration-test/blob/master/tools/clustering/cluster-monitor/monitor.py

Changes from the original script include:
 - Improved usability with curses (Terminal window is no longer broken
   after quitting the tool)
 - Integration with networking-odl ODL rest client (uses requests
   rather than pycurl)
 - Improved error detection and more accurate information displayed
   to user/operator
 - Installed as an executable in system path
 - Now meets pep8 requirements and is python3 compatible
 - Simplified logic and readability

Change-Id: Ib5028f74ccba592066a1f6db69344f9f9c2d48c3
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-03 14:54:11.000000000', 'message': 'Do not abort ata secure erase if drive security is in enabled state

At least in the case of INTEL SSDSC2BX016T4R drives, a
' hdparm --security-unlock' command does not remove the enabled line of the
security section of `hdparm -I`. As a consequence, the GenericHardwareManager
does not perform an ata secure erase (it relies on this line to be set
to `not enabled`).

For an INTEL SSDSC2BX016T4R, it has been manually verfied that the following
sequence of steps perform a secure erase sucessfully:

- hdparm --user-master u --security-unlock /dev/sda
- hdparm --user-master u --security-set-pass NULL /dev/sda
- hdparm --user-master u --security-erase-enhanced NULL /dev/sda

this is indicated by the "not enabled" line appearing in the output of
`hdparm -I /dev/sda`. It is therefore proposed that we do not actually care
if the `enabled` line appears in the output pre-erase. We should only verify
that is set to "not enabled" after an erase is attempted.

When we do not check the enabled line, the test
test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled becomes redundant with
test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled_unlock_exception taking its place.

As the tests are very dependent on the order of calls to `utils.execute`, I
added some asserts to the failure cases to ensure that the correct call was
failing.

Change-Id: I5d4e18e7d7209dda89181fbcc202b199f130af89
Story: 2001763
Task: 12162
'}, {'created': '2018-04-03 15:13:58.000000000', 'message': 'Do not abort ata secure erase if security is in enabled state

At least in the case of INTEL SSDSC2BX016T4R drives, a 'hdparm
--security-unlock' command does not remove the enabled line of the
security section of `hdparm -I`. As a consequence, the
GenericHardwareManager does not perform an ata secure erase (it relies
on this line to be set to `not enabled`).

For an INTEL SSDSC2BX016T4R, it has been manually verfied that the
following sequence of steps perform a secure erase sucessfully:

- hdparm --user-master u --security-unlock /dev/sda
- hdparm --user-master u --security-set-pass NULL /dev/sda
- hdparm --user-master u --security-erase-enhanced NULL /dev/sda

this is indicated by the "not enabled" line appearing in the output of
`hdparm -I /dev/sda`. It is therefore proposed that we do not actually
care if the `enabled` line appears in the output pre-erase. We should
only verify that is set to "not enabled" after an erase is attempted.

When we do not check the enabled line, the test
test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled becomes redundant with
test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled_unlock_exception taking its
place.

As the tests are very dependent on the order of calls to `utils.execute`, I
added some asserts to the failure cases to ensure that the correct call was
failing.

Change-Id: I5d4e18e7d7209dda89181fbcc202b199f130af89
Story: 2001763
Task: 12162

--security-unlock' command does not remove the enabled line of the
security section of `hdparm -I`. As a consequence, the
GenericHardwareManager does not perform an ata secure erase (it relies
on this line to be set to `not enabled`).

For an INTEL SSDSC2BX016T4R, it has been manually verfied that the
following sequence of steps perform a secure erase sucessfully:

- hdparm --user-master u --security-unlock /dev/sda
- hdparm --user-master u --security-set-pass NULL /dev/sda
- hdparm --user-master u --security-erase-enhanced NULL /dev/sda

this is indicated by the "not enabled" line appearing in the output of
`hdparm -I /dev/sda`. It is therefore proposed that we do not actually
care if the `enabled` line appears in the output pre-erase. We should
only verify that is set to "not enabled" after an erase is attempted.

When we do not check the enabled line, the test
test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled becomes redundant with
test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled_unlock_exception taking its
place.

As the tests are very dependent on the order of calls to `utils.execute`, I
added some asserts to the failure cases to ensure that the correct call was
failing.

Change-Id: I5d4e18e7d7209dda89181fbcc202b199f130af89

commit_message:
Do not abort ata secure erase if security is in enabled state

At least in the case of INTEL SSDSC2BX016T4R drives, a 'hdparm
--security-unlock' command does not remove the enabled line of the
security section of `hdparm -I`.  This is in accordance with
the ATA security specification, where a security-unlock command
causes a state transition from SEC4 (security enabled, locked,
not frozen) to SEC5 (security enabled, unlocked, not frozen).
As a consequence, the GenericHardwareManager does not perform an
ATA secure erase (it relies on this line to be set to `not enabled`).

For an INTEL SSDSC2BX016T4R, it has been manually verfied that the
following sequence of steps perform a secure erase sucessfully:

- hdparm --user-master u --security-unlock /dev/sda
- hdparm --user-master u --security-set-pass NULL /dev/sda
- hdparm --user-master u --security-erase-enhanced NULL /dev/sda

this is indicated by the "not enabled" line appearing in the output of
`hdparm -I /dev/sda`. It is therefore proposed that we do not actually
care if the `enabled` line appears in the output pre-erase. We should
only verify that is set to "not enabled" after an erase is attempted.

We need to ensure the device is the correct security state (SEC5) for
secure erase to succeed. If the device has just been unlocked, it
should already be in the SEC5 state and we do not need to set a
password. I have added an addition if statement to assert that it
is in the unlocked state after the unlock command. The frozen and
enabled status are already checked by exisiting logic.

A good overview of the ATA security states can be found here:

  http://www.admin-magazine.com/Archive/2014/19/Using-the-ATA-security-features-of-modern-hard-disks-and-SSDs

When we do not check the enabled line, the test
test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled becomes redundant with
test_erase_block_device_ata_security_enabled_unlock_exception taking its
place.

As the tests are very dependent on the order of calls to `utils.execute`, I
added some asserts to the failure cases to ensure that the correct call was
failing.

Change-Id: I5d4e18e7d7209dda89181fbcc202b199f130af89
Story: 2001763
Task: 12162

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-11 18:18:43.000000000', 'message': 'Flexibly test keystonmiddleware in placement stack

In change I524c93d30607ea6ab70de92ceea207ee77f34c25 keystonemiddleware
adjusted how the value of the Keystone uri is quoted when sending a
www-authenticate header. It went from using a single quote to double.
Double is more correct.

The existing version of the test changed in this commit relied on the
single quote to verify that a URL set in config would be used by the
middleware appropriately. Now, instead of one exact match test, two
in-string tests are used.

Change-Id: Ie9d1df419f2bdfa1d658f5f64ea9b7285de7b9b7
Closes-Bug: #1770718
'}]
commit_message:
Flexibly test keystonmiddleware in placement stack

In change I524c93d30607ea6ab70de92ceea207ee77f34c25 keystonemiddleware
adjusted how the value of the Keystone uri is quoted when sending a
www-authenticate header. It went from using a single quote to double.
Double is more correct.

The existing version of the test changed in this commit relied on the
single quote to verify that a URL set in config would be used by the
middleware appropriately. Now, instead of one exact match test, two
in-string tests are used.

Change-Id: Ie9d1df419f2bdfa1d658f5f64ea9b7285de7b9b7
Closes-Bug: #1770718

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-12 03:18:23.000000000', 'message': 'Add python-qinlingclient to global requirement

- Is the library actively maintained?

python-qinlingclient is actively maintained by qinling team.

- Is the library good code?

It has been developed following the OpenStack conventions and practices,
including pep8/hacking and unit testing.

- Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes, we have py3 gate job running for the submitted patches.

- Is the library license compatible?

Yes, python-qinlingclient uses the Apache Software License

- Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest /
  Fedora latest)?

No

- Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
  global-requirements.txt?

No. python-qinlingclient is meant for interacting with Qinling service.

- Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
  infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes. python-qinlingclient is meant for interacting with Qinling service.

- If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process does it
  use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

Yes

- Do I need to update anything else?

No

Change-Id: Ide609acb7493760cf373973f049035f7c97c7851

commit_message:
Add python-qinlingclient to global requirement

- Is the library actively maintained?

python-qinlingclient is actively maintained by qinling team.

- Is the library good code?

It has been developed following the OpenStack conventions and practices,
including pep8/hacking and unit testing.

- Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes, we have py3 gate job running for the submitted patches.

- Is the library license compatible?

Yes, python-qinlingclient uses the Apache Software License

- Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest /
  Fedora latest)?

No

- Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
  global-requirements.txt?

No. python-qinlingclient is meant for interacting with Qinling service.

- Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
  infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes. python-qinlingclient is meant for interacting with Qinling service.

- If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process does it
  use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

Yes

- Do I need to update anything else?

No

Change-Id: Ide609acb7493760cf373973f049035f7c97c7851

commit_message:
Add neutron-tempest-plugin to dynamic routing playbooks

* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/521346/ marks the switch to
  neutron-tempest-plugin. In order to consume the same, we need
  to add it to required projects under job definition of
  networking-dynamic-routing.

* Added reference for neutron-tempest-plugin to required projects.

Needed-By: I34efe893b93240c4689de1dda978209926022dfd
Change-Id: I7f552a23a3f59bf49c7460cbd3dfae813a140757

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-07 13:14:14.000000000', 'message': "Add special 'all' for deploy_on_servers server name to match all

This adds a special clause for when the value of server_name is
set to 'all'. In this case we skip the match on name and just
use the entire nova list. See related below for a use case.

Related:
(python-tripleoclient) I77fdc9deab97c785725f09b8529c512950753f86

Change-Id: Ic138c4925c5c96d1cf718af7ae59bcf5f0ba96dc
"}]
commit_message:
Add special 'all' for deploy_on_servers server name to match all

This adds a special clause for when the value of server_name is
set to 'all'. In this case we skip the match on name and just
use the entire nova list. See related below for a use case.

Related:
(python-tripleoclient) I77fdc9deab97c785725f09b8529c512950753f86

Change-Id: Ic138c4925c5c96d1cf718af7ae59bcf5f0ba96dc

'}, {'created': '2018-03-22 13:55:59.000000000', 'message': "TLS by default for the overcloud if no certificate provided

If no incoming cert/key is provided, this patch will request one to the
undercloud's local CA using certmonger and populate the required
parameters.

This is the first step on a series of patches to enable this
functionality. We still need to cover the case for updating this
certificate, and resubmitting the request to the CA if necessary.

Change-Id: I3d3cad0eb1396e7bee146794b29badad302efdf3

"}, {'created': '2018-03-27 05:17:24.000000000', 'message': "TLS by default for the overcloud if no certificate provided

If no incoming cert/key is provided, this patch will request one to the
undercloud's local CA using certmonger and populate the required
parameters.

This is the first step on a series of patches to enable this
functionality. We still need to cover the case for updating this
certificate, and resubmitting the request to the CA if necessary.

Change-Id: I3d3cad0eb1396e7bee146794b29badad302efdf3
"}, {'created': '2018-03-27 09:48:50.000000000', 'message': "TLS by default for the overcloud

This gets a TLS certificate for the overcloud when necessary:

* If no incoming cert/key is provided and we don't expect the
  overcloud's certmonger instances to request the certificates,
  we request one to the undercloud's certmonger local CA.

* If a certificate was provided, we verify if it's user-provided
  or if it was autogenerated.

  - If it was user-provided we pass through that certificate

  - If it was autogenerated, we request or resubmit the request
    if it's needed.

Change-Id: I3d3cad0eb1396e7bee146794b29badad302efdf3
"}, {'created': '2018-03-27 09:55:46.000000000', 'message': "TLS by default for the overcloud

commit_message:
TLS by default for the overcloud

This gets a TLS certificate for the overcloud when necessary:

* If no incoming cert/key is provided and we don't expect the
  overcloud's certmonger instances to request the certificates,
  we request one to the undercloud's certmonger local CA.

* If a certificate was provided, we verify if it's user-provided
  or if it was autogenerated.

  - If it was user-provided we pass through that certificate

  - If it was autogenerated, we request or resubmit the request
    if it's needed.

* We also accept the EnableTLS flag, which the deployer can
  explicitly turn off if they decide not to use TLS.

Depends-On: Ic70dd323b33596eaa3fc18bdc69a7c011ccd7fa1
Change-Id: I3d3cad0eb1396e7bee146794b29badad302efdf3

commit_message:
deploy/upgrade: include tripleo_role_name

"role_name" is internal to Ansible, we should not use it.
As a transition, include "tripleo_role_name" when calling Ansible and
once we're ready we'll remove the role_name var in a future patch.

Change-Id: Ib477b35ed1c062f2ea6c7d9d2d41ac58f3b275e2
Related-Bug: #1771171

when the domain is deleted, all its records are deleted as well.
Not ignoring such NotFound can lead to undeletable stacks if they

Closes-Bug: #1748953

commit_message:
Ignore dns domain NotFound when deleting record

when the domain is deleted, all its records are deleted as well.
Not ignoring such NotFound can lead to undeletable stacks if they
have a Designate::Record resource that references a deleted Designate
Domain.

Change-Id: If56f84b0b86f4d8136a1f83683a4a9eee5d89759
Closes-Bug: #1748953

subject: common-tasks: Do not sync preconfigured /etc/pip.conf file
messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-05-15 11:50:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-05-15 12:04:42.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nThis should not be used for pike, given it does not have the pip_default_index variable.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-15 11:50:53.000000000', 'message': "common-tasks: Do not sync preconfigured /etc/pip.conf file

Zuul places a /etc/pip.conf file on the host as shown below

2018-05-02 11:48:59.945452 | TASK [configure-mirrors : Install /etc/pip.conf configuration]

However, we don't need that since we have our own role to configure pip
which overrides the Zuul one anyway. For the hosts which are not
configured with the pip_install role, this can actually cause problems
so we wipe the file and we let our own role configure it the way we want
to.

Change-Id: I45a900b056db1c8a173f9ed1dae1bd998915e9d4
(cherry picked from commit c2030ef9741c095d6babe07b00ce6a30bed4245f)
"}]
commit_message:
common-tasks: Do not sync preconfigured /etc/pip.conf file

Zuul places a /etc/pip.conf file on the host as shown below

2018-05-02 11:48:59.945452 | TASK [configure-mirrors : Install /etc/pip.conf configuration]

However, we don't need that since we have our own role to configure pip
which overrides the Zuul one anyway. For the hosts which are not
configured with the pip_install role, this can actually cause problems
so we wipe the file and we let our own role configure it the way we want
to.

Change-Id: I45a900b056db1c8a173f9ed1dae1bd998915e9d4
(cherry picked from commit c2030ef9741c095d6babe07b00ce6a30bed4245f)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-02 13:16:40.000000000', 'message': "common-tasks: Do not sync preconfigured /etc/pip.conf file

Zuul places a /etc/pip.conf file on the host as shown below

2018-05-02 11:48:59.945452 | TASK [configure-mirrors : Install /etc/pip.conf configuration]

However, we don't need that since we have our own role to configure pip
which overrides the Zuul one anyway. For the hosts which are not
configured with the pip_install role, this can actually cause problems
so we wipe the file and we let our own role configure it the way we want
to.

Change-Id: I45a900b056db1c8a173f9ed1dae1bd998915e9d4
"}]
commit_message:
common-tasks: Do not sync preconfigured /etc/pip.conf file

Zuul places a /etc/pip.conf file on the host as shown below

2018-05-02 11:48:59.945452 | TASK [configure-mirrors : Install /etc/pip.conf configuration]

However, we don't need that since we have our own role to configure pip
which overrides the Zuul one anyway. For the hosts which are not
configured with the pip_install role, this can actually cause problems
so we wipe the file and we let our own role configure it the way we want
to.

Change-Id: I45a900b056db1c8a173f9ed1dae1bd998915e9d4

[{'created': '2018-05-09 09:04:00.000000000', 'message': "Do not sync pre-configured /etc/pip.conf file

Zuul places a /etc/pip.conf file on the host, but we don't need it
given that we have our own implementation of pip configuration which
uses the correct mirrors based on the mirror script.

As such, we do not want this file in the containers, so we should
no longer copy it into the container cache when it is prepared.

Change-Id: I4986ff4d21e9fa8b77115ab80c66de99afe45f6c
"}, {'created': '2018-05-09 09:36:02.000000000', 'message': 'Adjust inside/outside openstack-ci bootstrap-host tasks

To optimise the execution and to simplify it, we re-arrange the
tasks in such a way that there are only two blocks - one for
execution inside openstack-infra, and one for outside.

Also, Zuul places a /etc/pip.conf file on the host but we do not
need it given that we have our own implementation of pip config
which uses the correct mirrors based on the mirror script.
As such, we no longer want this file in the containers, so we
remove the setting which makes lxc_hosts copy it into the
container cache when it is prepared.

Change-Id: I4986ff4d21e9fa8b77115ab80c66de99afe45f6c
'}]
commit_message:
Adjust inside/outside openstack-ci bootstrap-host tasks

To optimise the execution and to simplify it, we re-arrange the
tasks in such a way that there are only two blocks - one for
execution inside openstack-infra, and one for outside.

Also, Zuul places a /etc/pip.conf file on the host but we do not
need it given that we have our own implementation of pip config
which uses the correct mirrors based on the mirror script.
As such, we no longer want this file in the containers, so we
remove the setting which makes lxc_hosts copy it into the
container cache when it is prepared.

Change-Id: I4986ff4d21e9fa8b77115ab80c66de99afe45f6c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-13 19:38:55.000000000', 'message': 'Add python-keystoneclient to the ansible-runtime venv

In order to reduce the packages required to pip install on to the hosts,
we install the extra library into the ansible-runtime venv so that tasks
interacting with keystone using our keystone module can do so by using
localhost delegation. Using this strategy, the library does not need to
be installed on the target host.

Change-Id: I7213252ac7fe59550379db3fe755996c1349a959
'}]
commit_message:
Add python-keystoneclient to the ansible-runtime venv

In order to reduce the packages required to pip install on to the hosts,
we install the extra library into the ansible-runtime venv so that tasks
interacting with keystone using our keystone module can do so by using
localhost delegation. Using this strategy, the library does not need to
be installed on the target host.

Change-Id: I7213252ac7fe59550379db3fe755996c1349a959

commit_message:
Create roles for Octavia API

This patch adds a parameter for enabling creation of keystone roles
matching Octavia's access policies.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/560031/
Change-Id: I4892c8d0893bca7c633bf271858c7b831338b38b
Closes-Bug: #1762774

commit_message:
Add deprecation notices for old SSL options in config.yaml...

Specifically for... `enable-pki`, `https-service-endpoints` and
`use-https`.

Change-Id: Ica2dfc39dc550b1aa43e178ae29fb333eeaca572

rabbitmqctl        rabbitmq-defaults  rabbitmq-env       rabbitmq-plugins   rabbitmq-server

The following plugins have been disabled:
  mochiweb
  webmachine
  rabbitmq_web_dispatch
  amqp_client

  rabbitmq_management

Applying plugin configuration to rabbit@juju-ccbd5c-nagios-ssl-3... failed.

(3 comments)

This looks pretty good, however I have a few notes on the unit tests permuting the system they are run on.

Also, the patch set needs to be rebased.'}, {'account_id': 2424, 'date': '2018-04-18 15:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2018-05-09 06:53:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2018-05-09 08:20:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

While it should be a last resort, it is perfectly fine for unit tests to generate data as long as it complies with the following:

 * data must be in a temporary file or directory
 * temp file or dir must be deleted once unit test completes
 * should ideally use 'with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile() as ftmp:' or similar so that the path is guaranteed to be deleted.

Temporary data must not remain or be allowed to accumulate and must be guaranteed to be in a unique temporary location so that it does not conflict with other tests."}, {'account_id': 2424, 'date': '2018-05-09 12:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-05-09 13:04:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2018-05-09 21:47:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2018-05-15 10:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Landing this as I value the functionality it gives over the color of the unit test bike shed.

But please, do refrain from creating unit tests that permutes the system in the future.'}]

commit_message:
Extend check_rabbitmq.py to honor ssl=only

This patch enables checks of rabbitmq when SSL is enabled, when ssl
config option is set to 'on' both ports (5672 and 5671) will be
checked.

Change-Id: Ia0bab1dca65112cd06ae382f6ebc1cc280d7b130
Closes-Bug: 1687916

commit_message:
Fix syntax for setting enabled_import_methods

Glance's enabled_import_methods is a ListOpt, and requires explicit
brackets around the list of values. It throws an error if the brackets
are missing.

Related-Bug: #1765439
Change-Id: I6d1b839bdd391a515bc630b32da2fbfcf007f01f

subject: Add psycopg2-binary to global-requirements
messages:
[{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-04-17 12:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-04-17 14:33:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Just to be clear, there is one package name for binary and one package name for source based installs?  Do wheels not work?

-1 for questoins'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-04-17 15:54:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Just to be clear, there is one package name for binary and one
 > package name for source based installs?  Do wheels not work?
 > 
 > -1 for questoins

That is my understanding, yes. The following warning, which is currently being spewed all over the nova logs, should explain things.

  nova/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/psycopg2/__init__.py:144: UserWarning: The psycopg2 wheel package will be renamed from release 2.8; in order to keep installing from binary please use "pip install psycopg2-binary" instead. For details see: <http://initd.org/psycopg/docs/install.html#binary-install-from-pypi>'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-04-17 19:56:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

That makes it sound like psycopg2 is going away in favor of psycopg2-binary.
I guess that's just bad error messaging."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-04-17 19:57:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I do wonder how they expect distros to handle this.  We'll probably have to sed out the binary version if it's defined in your requirements, not sure, needs investigation"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-04-18 09:42:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I do wonder how they expect distros to handle this.  We'll probably
 > have to sed out the binary version if it's defined in your
 > requirements, not sure, needs investigation

This is a pypi thing so it should only affect users installing from pip. Anyone packaging this for distros can continue to use python-psycopg2 or whatever as they always did, given that those packages will be compiled."}, {'account_id': 13404, 'date': '2018-04-18 09:46:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> This is a pypi thing so it should only affect users installing from
 > pip. Anyone packaging this for distros can continue to use
 > python-psycopg2 or whatever as they always did, given that those
 > packages will be compiled.

That is right, but we usually use to tools that track the requirements file to assist this. We are used to explicity drop some requirements (mostly used to testing and reporting) A full replacement of python-psycopg2 wih python-psycopg2-binary will need some update of those tools.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-04-18 15:06:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I think we need to add this to the blacklist, if it installs to the same namespace there are file colisions (even if it doesn't error out).  I think I'm fine with adding it though."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-04-21 02:24:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

This is a silly situation to be in but each vendor/distributor will need to handle this there own way.

As Stephen says from a distro POV the package doesn't change so this should mostly be a no-op there.  We will have a bunch of clean-up to do in anything that uses psycopg2 before we can accept the 2.8.0 version into g-r.

Probably needs a list discussion, or at least a heads up"}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-04-23 13:40:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I am confused what we're trying to do here. Is this only about test requirements? Then it should be added to the blacklist. Otherwise can projects choose one or the other or both?"}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-04-23 14:17:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

projects can only choose one, it installs to the same namespace'}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-05-04 06:34:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26285, 'date': '2018-05-04 06:40:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-05-06 05:26:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Right, but that means coinstallability is going to be difficult. Unless we switch globally this means all non-containerized deployments have to edit requirements to.match one of them globally.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-05-06 05:27:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Even in a devstack env we might have a virtualenv pulling in both?'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-05-15 10:06:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Waiting for an answer to the concerns raised :-)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-05-15 10:47:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Right, but that means coinstallability is going to be difficult.
 > Unless we switch globally this means all non-containerized
 > deployments have to edit requirements to.match one of them
 > globally.

Hmm, so there's a more detailed discussion on GitHub [1] and from the looks of things, this package split was intended to work issues with SSL libraries. Unfortunately they don't discuss a resolution to potential clobbering issues, likely because there isn't one. I've started a discussion on the mailing list [2] but at this time it seems we might be better off just requiring the installation of libpq once again. I'm going to abandon this until we have a better idea of how to approach this.

[1] https://github.com/psycopg/psycopg2/issues/674
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130497.html"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-05-15 10:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-17 12:23:13.000000000', 'message': "Add psycopg2-binary to global-requirements

psycopg2 2.8 will rename its wheel package to psycopg2-binary [1]. We
want to continue using this as it is the only way to avoid compiling
psycopg2 as a static library or installing the 'libpq' package.

* Is the library actively maintained?

Yes. This package is simply the binary package for psycopg2.

* Is the library good code?

Yes. It is the most popular PostgreSQL adapter for the Python
programming language.

* Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

* Is the library license compatible?

Yes.

* Is the library already packaged in the distros we target?

Yes (via the standard 'psycopg2' package - this package is only
necessary if installing from PyPi)

* Is the function of this library already, et cetera?

The psycopg2 library can be used instead, but doing so will require
compiling this library as a static library or installing the 'libpq'
package.

[1] http://initd.org/psycopg/docs/install.html#binary-install-from-pypi

Change-Id: I02490605b82abcedae71ed9cc6796bfb866cddcf
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Add psycopg2-binary to global-requirements

psycopg2 2.8 will rename its wheel package to psycopg2-binary [1]. We
want to continue using this as it is the only way to avoid compiling
psycopg2 as a static library or installing the 'libpq' package.

* Is the library actively maintained?

Yes. This package is simply the binary package for psycopg2.

* Is the library good code?

Yes. It is the most popular PostgreSQL adapter for the Python
programming language.

* Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

* Is the library license compatible?

Yes.

* Is the library already packaged in the distros we target?

Yes (via the standard 'psycopg2' package - this package is only
necessary if installing from PyPi)

* Is the function of this library already, et cetera?

The psycopg2 library can be used instead, but doing so will require
compiling this library as a static library or installing the 'libpq'
package.

[1] http://initd.org/psycopg/docs/install.html#binary-install-from-pypi

Change-Id: I02490605b82abcedae71ed9cc6796bfb866cddcf
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Ensure the CephX Manila keyring permissions are only set when needed

Do not try to set the ACLs on the Manila CephX keyring if the
CephFS backend is not enabled; in that case the keyring does not
exist.

Change-Id: I2f0018c66bd071f9e2e0dfafb0339a5b891ed71a
Closes-Bug: 1770444
(cherry picked from commit ce734ea1e23fec7e12da5d53610a0075a4100235)

commit_message:
Trivial: Fix the comment of TempestConfigPrivate

During the review of I98e75ed52f754a45d0774067fd1713bee2cecb64
I was confused due to this original comment because that is a
class and it is impossible to use a class from the same class.
This patch fixes the comment.

Change-Id: Ib14e53f3824d03154c65cf0106b5c2e1f2df13d5

subject: Fixes starting freezer-scheduler with --no-daemon
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-11 13:03:33.000000000', 'message': "Fixes starting freezer-scheduler with --no-daemon

When using flag --no-daemon, freezer-scheduler --no-daemon start fails with
AttributeError: 'NoDaemon' object has no attribute 'restart'
(freezer_scheduler.py: L251). This patch adds missing dummy methods for reload
and restart actions.

Change-Id: I72a0a4f68503b7c143cbe6c6f13cfbdc08e6ccbb
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes starting freezer-scheduler with --no-daemon

When using flag --no-daemon, freezer-scheduler --no-daemon start fails with
AttributeError: 'NoDaemon' object has no attribute 'restart'
(freezer_scheduler.py: L251). This patch adds missing dummy methods for reload
and restart actions.

Change-Id: I72a0a4f68503b7c143cbe6c6f13cfbdc08e6ccbb

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-27 13:59:02.000000000', 'message': "Add support for instance storage encryption

Add support for encryption of the underlying block device providing
storage for local instances.

This commit introduces a new juju storage binding and configuration
option to provide a single block device for use for local instance
storage; this block device is formatted and mounted at
/var/lib/nova/instances.  In a MAAS deployment, this could be a
bcache fronted device.

The configuration option is preferred over the Juju storage binding
if both are supplied.

This block device can optionally be encrypted using dm-crypt/LUKS
with encryption keys stored in Hashicorp Vault using vaultlocker.

vaultlocker ensures that keys are never persisted to local storage,
providing assurance around security of data at rest in the event
that disks/server are stolen.

Charm support is implemented using a new configuration option 'encrypt'
which when set enforces a mandatory relationship to an instance
of the vault application.

Copy the 'ephemeral-unmount' config option and assocaited code from
the ceph-osd and swift-storage charms to enable testing in cloudy
environments.

Change-Id: I772baa61f45ff430f706ec4864f3018488026148

commit_message:
Add support for instance storage encryption

Add support for encryption of the underlying block device providing
storage for local instances.

This commit introduces a new juju storage binding and configuration
option to provide a single block device for use for local instance
storage; this block device is formatted and mounted at
/var/lib/nova/instances.  In a MAAS deployment, this could be a
bcache fronted device.

The configuration option is preferred over the Juju storage binding
if both are supplied.

This block device can optionally be encrypted using dm-crypt/LUKS
with encryption keys stored in Hashicorp Vault using vaultlocker.

vaultlocker ensures that keys are never persisted to local storage,
providing assurance around security of data at rest in the event
that disks/server are stolen.

Charm support is implemented using a new configuration option 'encrypt'
which when set enforces a mandatory relationship to an instance
of the vault application.

Copy the 'ephemeral-unmount' config option and assocaited code from
the ceph-osd and swift-storage charms to enable testing in cloudy
environments.

Change-Id: I772baa61f45ff430f706ec4864f3018488026148

'}, {'created': '2018-04-25 10:54:18.000000000', 'message': "Add support for vault key management with vaultlocker

vaultlocker provides support for storage of encryption keys
for LUKS based dm-crypt device in Hashicorp Vault.

Add support for this key management approach for Ceph
Luminous or later.   Applications will block until vault
has been initialized and unsealed at which point OSD devices
will be prepared and booted into the Ceph cluster.

The dm-crypt layer is placed between the block device
parition and the top level LVM PV used to create VG's
and LV's to support OSD operation.

Vaultlocker enables a systemd unit for each encrypted
block device to perform unlocking during reboots of the
unit; ceph-volume will then detect the new VG/LV's and
boot the ceph-osd processes as required.

Note that vault/vaultlocker usage is only supported with
ceph-volume, which was introduced into the Ubuntu packages
as of the 12.2.4 point release for Luminous.  If vault is
configured as the key manager in deployments using older
versions, a hook error will be thrown with a blocked
status message to this effect.

Change-Id: I713492d1fd8d371439e96f9eae824b4fe7260e47
Depends-On: If73e7bd518a7bc60c2db08e2aa3a93dcfe79c0dd

commit_message:
Add support for vault key management with vaultlocker

vaultlocker provides support for storage of encryption keys
for LUKS based dm-crypt device in Hashicorp Vault.

Add support for this key management approach for Ceph
Luminous or later.   Applications will block until vault
has been initialized and unsealed at which point OSD devices
will be prepared and booted into the Ceph cluster.

The dm-crypt layer is placed between the block device
parition and the top level LVM PV used to create VG's
and LV's to support OSD operation.

Vaultlocker enables a systemd unit for each encrypted
block device to perform unlocking during reboots of the
unit; ceph-volume will then detect the new VG/LV's and
boot the ceph-osd processes as required.

Note that vault/vaultlocker usage is only supported with
ceph-volume, which was introduced into the Ubuntu packages
as of the 12.2.4 point release for Luminous.  If vault is
configured as the key manager in deployments using older
versions, a hook error will be thrown with a blocked
status message to this effect.

Change-Id: I713492d1fd8d371439e96f9eae824b4fe7260e47
Depends-On: If73e7bd518a7bc60c2db08e2aa3a93dcfe79c0dd
Depends-On: https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/159

commit_message:
Horizon dashboard install should trigger restart

When a new horizon dashboard is installed horizon
must be restarted to load the dashboard.

This changes the deps file so that the service
anchor is notified when a new dashboard package
has been installed.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/564811/
Change-Id: I72183bdd960c43a49f92a3bdc6d4c8ca1e367fab

commit_message:
Load options before importing packages

Importing modules from the package (rally plugin) can fail while trying
to access proper configuration options. To solve this issue, we need to
load options before loading modules itselves.

Change-Id: I387ed4f6af809e1306d30fb9903d65668eb14839

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-08 10:46:57.000000000', 'message': "Use secret_id's with vault-kv relation

In order to tighten the security around access to secrets stored
in a Vault KV secrets backend, generate a secret_id for each
accessing unit, using a response wrapping token which is passed
over the relation to the consuming application.

The consuming application will then use this token out-of-band of
Juju to retrieve the secret_id associated with the AppRole ID
directly from Vault.

Add a new action 'refresh-secrets' to force a renewal of secret_id's
and associated one-shot retrieval tokens across a deployment.

A token is only issued when a new approle is created or when
a refresh is initiated via the 'refresh-secrets' action.

Change-Id: I2cd173514377d65542ea4fa67ccf700ea4b6ab89
"}]
commit_message:
Use secret_id's with vault-kv relation

In order to tighten the security around access to secrets stored
in a Vault KV secrets backend, generate a secret_id for each
accessing unit, using a response wrapping token which is passed
over the relation to the consuming application.

The consuming application will then use this token out-of-band of
Juju to retrieve the secret_id associated with the AppRole ID
directly from Vault.

Add a new action 'refresh-secrets' to force a renewal of secret_id's
and associated one-shot retrieval tokens across a deployment.

A token is only issued when a new approle is created or when
a refresh is initiated via the 'refresh-secrets' action.

Change-Id: I2cd173514377d65542ea4fa67ccf700ea4b6ab89

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-25 16:50:26.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for block device encryption

Change-Id: I9b3f8cd2de412ee96e0139dba4d4abdf998ecaf2
'}, {'created': '2018-04-26 09:25:23.000000000', 'message': "Add support for block device encryption

Add new secrets-storage relation to vault, supporting the
use of block device encryption using dm-crypt/vaultlocker.

Prepared devices are now recorded in the local unit kv
store; this information is used to provide a list of
configured block devices to the swift-proxy charm,
rather than the previous best guess provided by
determine_block_devices.  This allows us to use the
dm-crypt device name, rather than the underlying
block device.

Encrypted block devices are unlocked on boot using
vaultlocker-decrypt systemd units (enabled by vaultlocker);
/etc/fstab entries for such devices make use of a

commit_message:
Add support for block device encryption

Add new secrets-storage relation to vault, supporting the
use of block device encryption using dm-crypt/vaultlocker.

Prepared devices are now recorded in the local unit kv
store; this information is used to provide a list of
configured block devices to the swift-proxy charm,
rather than the previous best guess provided by
determine_block_devices.  This allows us to use the
dm-crypt device name, rather than the underlying
block device.

Encrypted block devices are unlocked on boot using
vaultlocker-decrypt systemd units (enabled by vaultlocker);
/etc/fstab entries for such devices make use of a
x-systemd.requires option to ensure that the block device
is unlocked prior to attempting to mount it.

Add new storage binding to allow charm to be used with
Juju storage.

Add new ephemeral-unmount configuration option to allow
cloud ephemeral storage to be used for testing purposes;
update functional testing to use this option.  The behaviour
of 'overwrite' was changed to accomodate the use of
encrypted block devices.

Change-Id: I9b3f8cd2de412ee96e0139dba4d4abdf998ecaf2

Is there a related bug for this?'}, {'account_id': 28132, 'date': '2018-04-27 13:28:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Is there a related bug for this?

No, there isn't. The charm works, but when deployed using the bundle/openstack-base, it requires an extra configuration step. I.e if you just do juju deploy cs:bundle/openstack-base-XX, the solution will deploy, but not work, until the br-data is replaced with br-ex. By setting br-ex as the default, this would be avoided. I expect that a large number of deployments will be done using the bundle, this update would at least slimline the bundle deployment."}, {'account_id': 28132, 'date': '2018-05-15 09:53:54.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Not needed, fixable by config.'}]

commit_message:
Updated bridge-mappings, from br-data to br-ex.

When deploying bundle/openstack-54, the other charms/projects used
br-ex mapped to physnet1. The basic configuration example on the
project page also seems to reference the usage of br-ex and not
br-data for the first network. Hence, this caused a problem once
deployed, as the projects assumed different bridges to connect to
the physical network

Change-Id: Id6ea8eb3716fea1b05d0be2ec51ec305cafa9af2

commit_message:
Django 2.0 support

Replace django.core.urlresolves with django.urls

(In Django 2.0) The django.core.urlresolvers module is removed
in favor of its new location, django.urls.
It was deprecated in Django 1.10:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/releases/1.10/#id3

Note that this commit does not add py35dj20 like other horizon plugins
because there is no actual python unit tests in freezer-web-ui.

Older Django unit tests were dropped from tox.ini
as horizon dropped Django <=1.10 support in Rocky.

Change-Id: I38f3f05655324f2a5f38c6e8c6ab53ebaa42d4c8

commit_message:
base/nova-compute: install udev/systemd to satisfy dependencies

For Debian we use 'stretch-backports' image due to requirements of some
images. That means that we also have systemd from backports. This breaks
'open-iscsi' (base) and 'python-guestfs' (nova-compute) installation.
Solution is to install 'udev' and 'systemd' in proper versions.

INFO:kolla.common.utils.base:Some packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have
INFO:kolla.common.utils.base:requested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable
INFO:kolla.common.utils.base:distribution that some required packages have not yet been created
INFO:kolla.common.utils.base:or been moved out of Incoming.
INFO:kolla.common.utils.base:The following information may help to resolve the situation:
INFO:kolla.common.utils.base:The following packages have unmet dependencies:
INFO:kolla.common.utils.base: open-iscsi : Depends: udev but it is not going to be installed
INFO:kolla.common.utils.base:E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.

INFO:kolla.common.utils.nova-compute: python-guestfs : Depends: libguestfs0 (= 1:1.34.6-2) but it is not going to be installed
INFO:kolla.common.utils.nova-compute:E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.

Closes-bug: #1769850

Change-Id: I4865c279d665cf34fc150794c01368a1602319f0
(cherry picked from commit d50cc5d5d4a577ddd87f1e6bc77d25c509a31cb6)

commit_message:
Run inventory-manage.py from the ansible-runtime venv

bootstrap-ansible installs prettytables in the ansible-runtime
venv. inventory-manage.py requires prettytables, so should use
the venv.

Change-Id: I5bcc8f78ec8a1a175f0bfae3f38101d26e7e3803
(cherry picked from commit c0b691ec42d8cef281d6630e6f50e5ebf4c63b44)

commit_message:
Set netns_proc_dir and docker_mode in configmap for CNI Daemon

Enable the docker_mode and set the netns_proc_dir with '/host_proc'
as the mount point defined in the cni ds definition in configmap.

Closes-Bug: #1769815
Change-Id: I7bc0e92fb69118b9a1e9b58f9cf9cb7a3ea63a39
Signed-off-by: Peng Liu <pliu@redhat.com>

subject: Remove -U from pip install
messages: [{'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-03-21 00:58:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-03-26 02:17:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nNeed to review. thanks'}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-04-03 08:37:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-05-15 09:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 00:58:52.000000000', 'message': 'Remove -U from pip install

We install packages twice, the -U for pip install will update requirements
